snippet: Mr. de Vries, president of Medidata Solutions, whose systems help run medical trials, tells of how a lesson learned in ballroom dancing helped turn around a sales presentation disaster.
abstract: The Boss column features Medidata Solutions president Glen de Vries discussing his career and management technique. Photo (M)0
lead_paragraph: I COME from a family that loves dancing. When I was in high school my mother decided I should learn to dance, so she bought me ballroom dance lessons as a graduation gift. She believed people should be comfortable walking onto a dance floor with a partner. For a while, I was obsessive about dancing. One summer I painted a dance studio in exchange for more lessons. I was also obsessed with chemistry and physics in high school. In 1994, I graduated from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh with a bachelor's degree in biological sciences. My senior year, I got a job at the alumni relations office calling alumni for donations. I called one man with whom I had a lot in common, a doctor from Manhattan who had been a biology major. We met and I ended up working for him at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center on a research project after I graduated.
